title: Kind of feel like old Irelia was more reasonable than new
body:
Old Irelia wasn't bombarding your screen with Es and R and having ridiculous base damages. Her windowed power gave you far more time to handle her, especially in lane, compared to her no-downtime new passive that stays up for as long as she's touching you, which on top of her much-improved burst potential (IMO the real problem of the rework, nice 500 base damage on her R and spammable Q) is just a little too much killing power. Yeah, the old stun was annoying, but it was entirely a numbers issue and could be tweaked many different ways. Old Irelia was slippery through tenacity when outnumbered; new Irelia is just as slippery without the condition thanks to Q resets while also having a huge % DR soak as an emergency button. You can't really address new Irelia's issues with numbers changes, you'd have to start taking stuff out of her kit and I think we're going to keep seeing Irelia on the patch notes until Riot realizes this.

Also it doesn't help that her 2 skillshots are so ridiculously wide, especially her E which can stun you at least 3x as thick as the visual indicator might actually suggest. This isn't really a design flaw but it's certainly a massive headache.

I agree with you OP, I don't feel like Irelia's or Akali's rework put much thought into the concepts of 'counterplay'. In my honest opinion the majority of reworks seem to just overload previous kits with MORE things rather than cut and define clear weaknesses and strengths in a champion. This is doubly problematic when we take into consideration the poor state of runes and itemisation. I'm probably going to take a lot of flack for this but, I firmly believe the game was much easier to balance when all we had to worry about was overtuned stats. Stats are easy adjustments but new skills, interactions and what have you seriously powercreeps this game and turns an otherwise easy fix into balancing nightmares. 

On that note however, there has been a very good rework recently (Nunu) and I'm hoping riot takes more inspiration from that rework then the not so  great Irelia, Akali and Aatrox (please don't remove champions from the game) reworks.

Also new Irelia's E isn't that hard to side step.

That's not really a fair assessment, imo. You could just as easily argue that Irelia's old E punished *her* for getting ahead. Look at Jax for example. He can be super fed, jump on you with an unconditional stun, and burst-per-second you to death in the kill window of an assassin. If old Irelia was fed and engaged on you with Q, she lost her stun. It's just odd to me that there are so many other fighters with stuns in their kits, but it was Irelia's *conditional* stun that was considered too toxic to exist. 

"But if you got ahead, she would just stun and run/turn the fight." Ok, how's that different from:

{{champion:92}} stun 
{{champion:164}} stun, ult 
{{champion:150}} transform, stun 
{{champion:240}} remount 
{{champion:23}} ult
{{champion:2}} passive
{{champion:19}} Q triple heal
{{champion:106}} passive
{{champion:48}} ult
That precision rune that increases damage based on your missing health

1) Those guys reward them for using their abilities well or winning the fight. Irelia's E rewards her for *losing* the fight, then ripping the carpet from under you and beating on you while you can't move with no counter-play outside of "Lose the fight up to a point, then burst her down before she can finish you off", which is insanely clumsy to have to work around.

2) If old Irelia engaged on you while fed, she didn't exactly *need* a stun to kill you, anyway. New Irelia can't slow you without ulting. If you dodge the stun you're not getting unconditionally slowed while she cuts you.

>Irelia's E rewards her for losing the fight

Just to clarify, do you think it would have been more fair if Equilibrium Strike was just a plain old unconditional stun? What made her E specifically unfair compared to the other stuns I mentioned (eg long duration at max rank, targeting, etc)?

>Those guys reward them for using their abilities well or winning the fight.

Really not true, though. Trynd can ult through any cc and turn a fight exactly the way Irelia used to. Warwick, Voli, and Olaf get massive heal/sustain spikes at low health, allowing them to drain-tank losing fights. Trundle's steals more stats from you when you're ahead. Kled's dismount (burst immunity and untargetability) and remount are both capable of turning a fight and punish you for winning and being in range to finish him off.

>If old Irelia engaged on you while fed, she didn't exactly need a stun to kill you, anyway.

Fair point, but at least she had weaknesses that could be exploited outside of laning. Her late game, team fight, and utility weren't great, and she had telegraphed windows of power with her W. Now she's loaded with all the same problems as Camille but without the level 6+ vulnerability and enforced burst delays.

If the only problem with old Irelia was her E targeting and tenacity passive, Riot could have reworked those without turning her into a balance abomination.

I feel like I'm one of the few players who prefers old Irelia. New Irelia completely changed Irelia's kit and build from an AA based champ to a bursty bruiser. New Irelia has almost no differing ability path to old irelia where you would sometimes start E against hard matchups. I also prefer Irelia's old Q even though it was harder to cs with, it felt a lot smoother. I don't entirely have an issue with the skill requirement changes or build paths but I do have an issue with how they completely changed her kit/gameplay. Yes, they did keep her Q but they completely changed her damage output, ultimate, and teamfight/laning phase. . Old irelia was more controlled with the sheen powerspike and could acutally be abused in lane but new Irelia has a W that basically negates damage and CC and your entire goal is to stack up conqueror on minions and to hit level 2 for firstblood all-in. Even though new irelia has skillshots that debately take more skill, I still think old-irelia took more skill because the Q damage against minions wasn't amplified so chasing/kiting/procing sheen took more risky decision making. New irelia you just all-in whenever your E and Q are up and just reset, and missing combos doesn't really hurt you in lane, especially since Q damage is amplified on minions as a handicap wheras old Irelia didn't. Just my 2 cents, not everyone might agree with me but I did main old irelia. It's also a lot easier to play successfully as new irelia than old irelia and this is proven by players picking her up and winning games with almost no experience as a top laner or irelia player in general. Basically I feel the rework removed the uniqueness of being an "Irelia Player"

The only reason why she's so "oppressive" is the fact she just shreds through resists due to conqueror's true damage. Remove that and all you would have to do as either a tank or bruiser is build Adaptive Helm, Tabis, and any armor items you need/want and she'll just do less. This can be said about almost every other champ that can use and uses the rune: Darius, Fiora, Jax, Renekton, Udyr (if he goes AD Tiger), Master Yi, Kled, Draven, Tryndamere, Olaf (Top Lane Olaf), and Riven. If there is anything to learn from Conqueror, its a balancing error waiting to happen. 
Conqueror needs the true damage to be changed to something else if you want a healthy balance of tanks and bruisers in top lane. Long as the true damage exists, bruiser champions (and Draven) will be hard to balance. If you want a reason why armor just seems "not worth it", the true damage is where the fault lies.

Try playing Irelia with anything except Conqueror (like grasp, pta or fleet) and see how she fails to do anything. I can't tell if she was balanced around the keystone (since they came out about the same time) or the keystone is just so dumb that every bruiser needs it to be playable.
If I had to say, it was likely both.
